articles.title: Astronomers just captured the sharpest view of a distant star ever seen
articles.summary: A UCLA-led team has achieved the sharpest-ever view of a distant star’s disk using a groundbreaking photonic lantern device on a single telescope—no multi-telescope array required. This technology splits incoming starlight into multiple channels, revealing previously hidden details of space objects.
articles.content:
Key Takeaways

Sharper views from a single telescope: Normally, astronomers link multiple telescopes together to get the clearest images of distant stars and galaxies. A UCLA-led team has now achieved record-breaking detail of the star beta Canis Minoris using just one telescope equipped with a breakthrough device called a photonic lantern.

Normally, astronomers link multiple telescopes together to get the clearest images of distant stars and galaxies. A UCLA-led team has now achieved record-breaking detail of the star beta Canis Minoris using just one telescope equipped with a breakthrough device called a photonic lantern. How it works: The photonic lantern divides starlight into many fine channels that capture subtle spatial patterns. Advanced computational techniques then combine these channels to rebuild a high-resolution image filled with details that would otherwise be lost.

The photonic lantern divides starlight into many fine channels that capture subtle spatial patterns. Advanced computational techniques then combine these channels to rebuild a high-resolution image filled with details that would otherwise be lost. A new frontier for astronomy: This innovative approach could let scientists explore objects that are smaller, fainter, and farther away than ever before, offering fresh insight into the hidden structure of the universe and sparking new discoveries.

A Breakthrough View From a Single Telescope

For the first time, astronomers have used a new imaging method on a ground-based telescope to capture the most detailed look ever at the disk surrounding a distant star. Led by UCLA researchers, the achievement revealed hidden structures that had never been seen before. This breakthrough paves the way for scientists to study finer details of stars, planets, and other celestial objects, potentially transforming how we explore the universe.

A telescope's ability to reveal faint or distant objects depends on its size. Larger telescopes can collect more light, allowing them to see dimmer targets and produce sharper images. The highest levels of detail are usually reached by linking multiple telescopes together to form an array. Building these large instruments, or connecting them, has long been the key to achieving the precision needed for discovering new cosmic features.

Harnessing Light With a Photonic Lantern

Using a device called a photonic lantern, astronomers can now make better use of the light gathered by a telescope to produce extremely high-resolution images. The details of this breakthrough appear in Astrophysical Journal Letters.

"In astronomy, the sharpest image details are usually obtained by linking telescopes together. But we did it with a single telescope by feeding its light into a specially designed optical fiber, called a photonic lantern. This device splits the starlight according to its patterns of fluctuation, keeping subtle details that are otherwise lost. By reassembling the measurements of the outputs, we could reconstruct a very high-resolution image of a disk around a nearby star," said first author and UCLA doctoral candidate Yoo Jung Kim.

The photonic lantern divides the incoming light into multiple channels based on how the light wavefront is shaped, much like separating the notes of a musical chord. It also divides light by color, creating a rainbow-like spectrum. The device was designed and built by the University of Sydney and the University of Central Florida, and it forms part of the instrument FIRST-PL, developed and led by the Paris Observatory and the University of Hawai'i. This system is installed on the Subaru Coronagraphic Extreme Adaptive Optics instrument at the Subaru Telescope in Hawai'i, which is operated by the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan.

"What excites me most is that this instrument blends cutting-edge photonics with the precision engineering done here in Hawai'i," said Sebastien Vievard, a faculty member in the Space Science and Engineering Initiative at the University of Hawai'i who helped lead the build. "It shows how collaboration across the world, and across disciplines, can literally change the way we see the cosmos."

Pushing Beyond Traditional Imaging Limits

This method of separating and analyzing light enables a new way to see fine detail, achieving sharper resolution than traditional telescope cameras.

"For any telescope of a given size, the wave nature of light limits the fineness of the detail that you can observe with traditional imaging cameras. This is called the diffraction limit, and our team has been working to use a photonic lantern to advance what is achievable at this frontier," said UCLA professor of physics and astronomy Michael Fitzgerald.

"This work demonstrates the potential of photonic technologies to enable new kinds of measurement in astronomy," said Nemanja Jovanovic, a co-leader of the study at the California Institute of Technology. "We are just getting started. The possibilities are truly exciting."

At first, the researchers faced a major challenge: turbulence in Earth's atmosphere. The same shimmering effect that makes distant horizons appear wavy on a hot day causes starlight to flicker and distort as it travels through the air. To correct for this, the Subaru Telescope team used adaptive optics, a technology that continuously adjusts to cancel out these distortions and stabilize the light waves in real time.

"We need a very stable environment to measure and recover spatial information using this fiber," said Kim. "Even with adaptive optics, the photonic lantern was so sensitive to the wavefront fluctuations that I had to develop a new data processing technique to filter out the remaining atmospheric turbulence."

Exploring Beta Canis Minoris in Stunning Detail

The team put their technique to the test by observing the star beta Canis Minoris (β CMi), located about 162 light-years away in the constellation Canis Minor. This star is surrounded by a fast-spinning hydrogen disk. As the gas in the disk moves, the side rotating toward Earth appears bluer, while the side moving away looks redder, a result of the Doppler effect (the same phenomenon that changes the pitch of a moving car's sound). These color shifts slightly alter the apparent position of the starlight depending on its wavelength.

By applying new computational methods, the researchers measured these color-based position shifts with about five times more precision than ever before. In addition to confirming the rotation of the disk, they discovered that it is lopsided.

"We were not expecting to detect an asymmetry like this, and it will be a task for the astrophysicists modeling these systems to explain its presence," said Kim.

A New Way to See the Universe

This innovative approach will allow astronomers to observe smaller and more distant objects with unprecedented clarity. It may help solve long-standing cosmic mysteries and, as in the case of the lopsided disk around β CMi, uncover entirely new ones.

The project involved an international collaboration that included scientists from the Space Science and Engineering Initiative at the University of Hawai'i, the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan, the California Institute of Technology, the University of Arizona, the Astrobiology Center in Japan, the Paris Observatory, the University of Central Florida, the University of Sydney, and the University of California Santa Cruz.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant breakthrough in astronomical imaging technology that allows a single telescope to capture the sharpest-ever view of a distant star's disk. This advancement has broad implications for space exploration and scientific understanding of the universe, enabling observation of smaller, fainter, and more distant celestial objects with unprecedented clarity. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a meaningful technological innovation with wide scientific impact.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers capture the clearest view of a distant star using a single telescope
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Usually, to get very clear images of distant stars, astronomers connect many telescopes together to create a bigger, more powerful system. This helps them see tiny details far away in space that a single telescope might miss.

**What happened** – A team of scientists led by UCLA used a new device called a photonic lantern on just one telescope to take the sharpest-ever picture of the star beta Canis Minoris. This device splits the star’s light into many parts, which are then combined using computers to create a highly detailed image. They used this method on the Subaru Telescope in Hawai’i, which usually needs many telescopes working together to get such clear views.

**Impact** – This new technology lets astronomers see smaller and fainter objects in space with much better detail than before, without needing large groups of telescopes. For example, they discovered that the gas disk around the star beta Canis Minoris is uneven, a feature scientists had not seen until now. This could help researchers learn more about how stars and planets form.

**What's next step** – The team will continue improving this technique and use it to study other stars and space objects. This may lead to new discoveries about the universe’s structure and how cosmic systems behave. The method also shows how combining advanced technology and teamwork across countries can open new doors in space research.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By using a special device on a single telescope, astronomers have taken the clearest images yet of a distant star, opening new possibilities for exploring space in greater detail.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes capturent la vue la plus nette d’une étoile lointaine avec un seul télescope
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Habituellement, pour obtenir des images très nettes d’étoiles lointaines, les astronomes relient plusieurs télescopes ensemble pour former un système plus puissant. Cela leur permet de voir des détails très petits dans l’espace qu’un seul télescope ne pourrait pas capter.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe menée par l’Université de Californie à Los Angeles (UCLA) a utilisé un nouvel appareil appelé lanterne photonique sur un seul télescope pour prendre l’image la plus nette jamais réalisée de l’étoile bêta Canis Minoris. Cet appareil divise la lumière de l’étoile en plusieurs parties, qui sont ensuite recombinées par ordinateur pour créer une image très détaillée. Ils ont utilisé cette méthode sur le télescope Subaru à Hawaï, qui utilise habituellement plusieurs télescopes pour obtenir des images aussi claires.

**Impact** – Cette nouvelle technologie permet aux astronomes de voir des objets plus petits et plus faibles dans l’espace avec beaucoup plus de détails, sans avoir besoin de grands groupes de télescopes. Par exemple, ils ont découvert que le disque de gaz autour de l’étoile bêta Canis Minoris est inégal, une caractéristique jamais vue auparavant. Cela pourrait aider les chercheurs à mieux comprendre comment se forment les étoiles et les planètes.

**Prochaine étape** – L’équipe va continuer à améliorer cette technique et l’utiliser pour étudier d’autres étoiles et objets spatiaux. Cela pourrait conduire à de nouvelles découvertes sur la structure de l’univers et le comportement des systèmes cosmiques. Cette méthode montre aussi comment la technologie avancée et la collaboration internationale peuvent ouvrir de nouvelles voies en recherche spatiale.

**Résumé en une phrase** – En utilisant un appareil spécial sur un seul télescope, les astronomes ont pris les images les plus nettes d’une étoile lointaine, ouvrant de nouvelles possibilités pour explorer l’espace en plus grand détail.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos capturan la vista más clara de una estrella lejana con un solo telescopio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Normalmente, para obtener imágenes muy claras de estrellas lejanas, los astrónomos conectan varios telescopios para formar un sistema más potente. Esto les ayuda a ver detalles muy pequeños en el espacio que un solo telescopio no podría captar.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo liderado por UCLA usó un nuevo dispositivo llamado linterna fotónica en un solo telescopio para tomar la imagen más clara jamás lograda de la estrella beta Canis Minoris. Este dispositivo divide la luz de la estrella en muchas partes, que luego se combinan con computadoras para crear una imagen con mucho detalle. Usaron este método en el Telescopio Subaru en Hawái, que normalmente necesita varios telescopios juntos para obtener vistas tan nítidas.

**Impacto** – Esta nueva tecnología permite a los astrónomos ver objetos más pequeños y tenues en el espacio con mucho más detalle, sin necesitar grandes grupos de telescopios. Por ejemplo, descubrieron que el disco de gas alrededor de la estrella beta Canis Minoris es desigual, una característica que antes no se había visto. Esto puede ayudar a los científicos a entender mejor cómo se forman las estrellas y planetas.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo continuará mejorando esta técnica y la usará para estudiar otras estrellas y objetos espaciales. Esto podría llevar a nuevos descubrimientos sobre la estructura del universo y cómo funcionan los sistemas cósmicos. Este método también muestra cómo la tecnología avanzada y la colaboración internacional pueden abrir nuevas oportunidades en la investigación espacial.

**Resumen en una frase** – Usando un dispositivo especial en un solo telescopio, los astrónomos han tomado las imágenes más claras de una estrella lejana, abriendo nuevas posibilidades para explorar el espacio con mayor detalle.

articles.title: The Universe’s first radio waves could reveal dark matter
articles.summary: Researchers propose that hydrogen gas from the early Universe emitted detectable radio waves influenced by dark matter. Studying these signals, especially from the Moon’s radio-quiet environment, could reveal how dark matter clumped together before the first stars formed. This approach opens a new window into the mysterious cosmic era just 100 million years after the Big Bang.
articles.content:
For the first time, researchers at Tel Aviv University have predicted what might be discovered by detecting radio waves that originated in the early Universe. Their results suggest that during the "cosmic dark ages," dark matter gathered into dense clumps across space, pulling in hydrogen gas that emitted intense radio waves. This new approach could offer a way to investigate one of science's biggest mysteries: the true nature of dark matter.

The work, led by Prof. Rennan Barkana from Tel Aviv University's Sackler School of Physics and Astronomy, involved Ph.D. student Sudipta Sikder and collaborators from Japan, India, and the United Kingdom. Their findings were published in Nature Astronomy.

Studying the Cosmic Dark Ages from the Moon

According to the researchers, the cosmic dark ages (the period just before the first stars formed) can be explored by detecting radio waves emitted by the hydrogen gas that once filled the Universe. Although everyday antennas easily detect radio waves, the signals from this ancient era are blocked by Earth's atmosphere. Studying them requires instruments in space -- especially on the moon, where the lack of an atmosphere and human-made interference provides ideal conditions.

Building a telescope on the lunar surface is a formidable task, but the timing may be right. A global race is underway to return to the moon, with the United States, Europe, China, and India all pursuing new lunar missions. These agencies are seeking meaningful scientific objectives for future moon projects, and this new research underscores the potential of lunar-based radio astronomy to probe the early Universe.

Exploring the Universe Before the First Stars

Prof. Barkana explains: "NASA's new James Webb space telescope discovered recently distant galaxies whose light we receive from early galaxies, around 300 million years after the Big Bang. Our new research studies an even earlier and more mysterious era: the cosmic dark ages, only 100 million years after the Big Bang. Computer simulations predict that dark matter throughout the Universe was forming dense clumps, which would later help form the first stars and galaxies. The predicted size of these nuggets depends on, and thus can help illuminate, the unknown properties of dark matter, but they cannot be seen directly. However, these dark matter clumps pulled in hydrogen gas and caused it to emit stronger radio waves. We predict that the cumulative effect of all this can be detected with radio antennas that measure the average radio intensity on the sky."

These simulations suggest that radio signals from the dark ages, while faint, carry valuable clues about the invisible structures that seeded the formation of galaxies. Detecting them could transform our understanding of the Universe's earliest moments.

From the Cosmic Dark Ages to the Dawn of Stars

Although the expected signal is weak, successfully observing it could open a new window for testing theories of dark matter. When the first stars appeared shortly afterward, during a phase known as the "cosmic dawn," their light likely amplified this radio emission dramatically. Signals from that later era should be easier to detect with ground-based telescopes, though they are harder to interpret because star formation introduces additional complexity.

To tackle this challenge, scientists are turning to vast radio telescope networks designed to map subtle variations in cosmic radio intensity. One of the largest efforts is the Square Kilometre Array (SKA), a global collaboration involving an array of 80,000 radio antennas currently under construction in Australia. Prof. Barkana plays a key role in this international project, which aims to capture patterns of strong and weak radio emissions that could reveal where dark matter clumps once existed.

A New Window Into Dark Matter's Origins

The team believes that their predictions may provide an important step forward in understanding dark matter. Today, dark matter is intertwined with galaxies and stars, making its properties difficult to isolate. In contrast, the early Universe offers a pristine setting -- essentially an untouched laboratory -- for investigating how dark matter behaves without interference from later cosmic structures.

Prof. Barkana concludes: "Just as old radio stations are being replaced with newer technology that brings forth websites and podcasts, astronomers are expanding the reach of radio astronomy. When scientists open a new observational window, surprising discoveries usually result. The holy grail of physics is to discover the properties of dark matter, the mysterious substance that we know constitutes most of the matter in the Universe, yet we do not know much about its nature and properties. Understandably, astronomers are eager to start tuning into the cosmic radio channels of the early Universe."

This discovery has broad implications for understanding the cosmos and involves international collaboration and upcoming lunar exploration missions, representing a meaningful advance in space science with potential large-scale impact.
articles.personality_title: Scientists plan to use moon-based radio waves to study dark matter from the early Universe
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists want to learn more about dark matter, a mysterious substance that makes up most of the matter in the Universe but is invisible and hard to study. They focus on a very early time in space history called the cosmic dark ages, about 100 million years after the Big Bang, before the first stars appeared.

**What happened** – Researchers at Tel Aviv University predicted that hydrogen gas in the early Universe gave off radio waves influenced by dark matter clumps. These radio waves are blocked by Earth’s atmosphere but could be detected from the Moon, where there is no atmosphere or human noise. Their study, published in Nature Astronomy, involved international scientists and suggests building a radio telescope on the Moon to catch these ancient signals.

**Impact** – This idea is important because it offers a new way to explore the early Universe and understand dark matter better. Detecting radio waves from this time could show how dark matter formed clumps that helped create stars and galaxies. It opens a fresh path to study something that cannot be seen directly, using technology planned for future moon missions and big projects like the Square Kilometre Array on Earth.

**What's next step** – Scientists will work on building instruments to detect these faint radio signals, possibly on the Moon. Meanwhile, Earth-based telescopes like the Square Kilometre Array will continue to study related signals from slightly later times. Together, these efforts might soon provide clear clues about dark matter’s properties and the Universe’s first structures.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New research shows that radio waves from the early Universe, best observed from the Moon, could reveal how dark matter shaped the cosmos before stars were born.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques prévoient d'utiliser les ondes radio lunaires pour étudier la matière noire de l'Univers primitif
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques cherchent à mieux comprendre la matière noire, une substance mystérieuse qui compose la majeure partie de la matière dans l’Univers, mais qui est invisible et difficile à étudier. Ils s’intéressent à une époque très ancienne appelée les âges sombres cosmiques, environ 100 millions d’années après le Big Bang, avant l’apparition des premières étoiles.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Tel Aviv ont prédit que le gaz d’hydrogène dans l’Univers primitif émettait des ondes radio influencées par des amas de matière noire. Ces ondes sont bloquées par l’atmosphère terrestre mais pourraient être détectées depuis la Lune, où il n’y a ni atmosphère ni bruit humain. Leur étude, publiée dans Nature Astronomy, a réuni des scientifiques internationaux et suggère de construire un radiotélescope lunaire pour capter ces signaux anciens.

**Impact** – Cette idée est importante car elle offre un nouveau moyen d’explorer l’Univers primitif et de mieux comprendre la matière noire. Détecter ces ondes radio pourrait montrer comment la matière noire a formé des amas qui ont aidé à créer les étoiles et les galaxies. Cela ouvre une nouvelle voie pour étudier quelque chose d’invisible, grâce à la technologie prévue pour les futures missions lunaires et des projets majeurs comme le Square Kilometre Array sur Terre.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont travailler à la construction d’instruments capables de détecter ces signaux faibles, possiblement sur la Lune. En parallèle, des télescopes terrestres comme le Square Kilometre Array continueront d’étudier des signaux liés à des périodes un peu plus récentes. Ensemble, ces efforts pourraient bientôt fournir des indices clairs sur les propriétés de la matière noire et les premières structures de l’Univers.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une nouvelle recherche montre que les ondes radio de l’Univers primitif, mieux observées depuis la Lune, pourraient révéler comment la matière noire a façonné le cosmos avant la naissance des étoiles.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos planean usar ondas de radio desde la Luna para estudiar la materia oscura del Universo temprano
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos quieren entender mejor la materia oscura, una sustancia misteriosa que forma la mayor parte de la materia en el Universo pero que es invisible y difícil de estudiar. Se enfocan en un tiempo muy temprano llamado las edades oscuras cósmicas, unos 100 millones de años después del Big Bang, antes de que aparecieran las primeras estrellas.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Tel Aviv predijeron que el gas de hidrógeno en el Universo temprano emitía ondas de radio influenciadas por agrupaciones de materia oscura. Estas ondas no llegan a la Tierra por la atmósfera, pero podrían detectarse desde la Luna, donde no hay atmósfera ni ruido humano. Su estudio, publicado en Nature Astronomy, involucró a científicos de varios países y sugiere construir un radiotelescopio lunar para captar estas señales antiguas.

**Impacto** – Esta idea es importante porque ofrece una nueva forma de explorar el Universo temprano y entender mejor la materia oscura. Detectar estas ondas de radio podría mostrar cómo la materia oscura formó grupos que ayudaron a crear estrellas y galaxias. Abre un camino nuevo para estudiar algo invisible, usando tecnología planeada para futuras misiones lunares y grandes proyectos como el Square Kilometre Array en la Tierra.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos trabajarán en construir instrumentos para detectar estas señales débiles, posiblemente en la Luna. Mientras tanto, telescopios terrestres como el Square Kilometre Array seguirán estudiando señales relacionadas de épocas un poco más recientes. Juntos, estos esfuerzos podrían pronto dar pistas claras sobre las propiedades de la materia oscura y las primeras estructuras del Universo.

**Resumen en una frase** – Una nueva investigación muestra que las ondas de radio del Universo temprano, mejor observadas desde la Luna, podrían revelar cómo la materia oscura moldeó el cosmos antes del nacimiento de las estrellas.
articles.image_prompt: A serene lunar landscape bathed in soft golden light, featuring a delicate array of radio antennas gently curving like branches, reaching toward a vast starry sky where glowing clumps of dark matter pull in wisps of glowing hydrogen gas emitting faint, warm radio waves, symbolizing the cosmic dark ages before the first stars.
